entries.meaning: simple past tense and past participle of beard

description: From Middle English berded, from Old English ġebearded, ġebeardede, ġebierd, ġebierde (“bearded”), from Proto-Germanic *bardidaz (“bearded”), equivalent to beard +‎ -ed. Cognate with Dutch bebaarde (“bearded”), Middle Low German bārt (“bearded”), archaic German gebartet (“bearded”).

adjectives.description: bearded (comparative more bearded, superlative most bearded) (possessional)

entries.meaning: Having a beard; involving a beard.
examples: There are who in soft Eunuchs place their Bliss; / To shun the Scrubbing of a bearded Kiss, / And 'scape Abortion; but their solid Joy / Is when the Page, already past a Boy, / Is Capon'd late; and to the Gelder shown, / With his two Pounders to Perfection grown. / When all the Navel string cou'd give, appears; / All but the Beard, and that's the Barber's loss, not theirs.

entries.meaning: Having a fringe or appendage resembling a beard in some way (often followed by with).
examples: [...] but the joyous sea / Shall be our raiment, and the bearded star / Shoot arrows at our pleasure!

entries.meaning: (Of an axe) having the lower portion of the axehead extending the cutting edge significantly below the width of the butt, thus providing a wide cutting surface while keeping overall weight low.
(in combination) Having a beard (or similar appendage) of a specified type.
examples: [...] for with his hammer Thor / Smote 'mid the rocks the lichen-bearded pines / And burst their roots [...]
